awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Managing Network Function Virtualization under Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
Data centers are increasingly virtualizing network functions that have been traditionally implemented as hardware appliances.  Today's network functions (such as firewalls and multimedia support systems) are costly to procure, deploy, and change. With virtualization, these network  functions can instead be implemented as software running on low cost commodity servers. Their placement, size and connectivity can be adjustable on-demand though management and orchestration systems.

This project seeks to develop the theoretic foundations and practical implementations to achieve provably efficient, low-cost, and robust Network Function Virtualization (NFV) operation in dynamic and uncertain environments.  The project will develop online algorithms for placing, scaling and migrating virtualized network functions that take uncertain future network traffic and compute workloads into consideration. The investigators will model the variability and uncertainty of the compute load and network traffic in a rigorous mathematical framework to develop control algorithms with provable guarantees in cost and performance. The three principal research activities are: 1) exploring online NFV orchestration and scaling under uncertainty; 2) managing end-to-end queueing performance under uncertainty and cross-function dependency; and 3) designing algorithms and analyzing key performance and complexity bottlenecks.

por.por_cntn:
Our society has become dependent upon the efficient and reliable service of critical IT infrastructures, including ISP (internet service provider) backbones and cloud environments. Network functions, including firewalls, caches, WAN optimizers, and IP multimedia systems (IMSes), are already an essential and expensive part of today's networks. When implemented by dedicated hardware middleboxes, these network functions are costly to procure, deploy, and change. With NFV (network functions virtualization), these functions can instead be implemented as software running on low-cost mass-volume commodity servers. Their placement, size and connectivity (often referred to as NFV orchestration) can be adjusted on-demand, promising significant improvement in the efficiency and flexibility of service provider networks. 

However, such efficiency/adaptivity of NFV does not come for free because there are significant costs and constraints when the NFV system is reconfigured in response to network changes. Existing studies on NFV orchestration often focus on a static setting, i.e., they assume that the load and network conditions are fixed. As a result, they can produce unfavorable system configurations that, when future load and network conditions change in dynamic and uncertain ways, become costly (to adjust) and suffer poor network performance. Hence, there is a pressing need to understand at a fundamental level how to plan and adapt NFV operations with future variability and uncertainty in mind to minimize disruptions and operating costs in such a dynamic environment. Without such a solid understanding, the promised benefits of NFV will be greatly diminished due to inefficient utilization of computational and communication resources, and frequent degradation of client performance.

The goal of this project at Purdue University is to develop the theoretic foundations and practical implementations to achieve provably efficient, low-cost, and robust NFV operation in dynamic and uncertain  environments.  The key novelty of our proposed research is twofold. First, we model the variability and uncertainty of the load and network in a rigorous mathematical framework. Thus, unlike prior work that focuses on a static set of network requirements given beforehand, the algorithms and systems developed in this project provide provable performance guarantees even when future demand is variable and uncertain. Second, we unify theoretic development with implementations that take practical constraints into account. Specifically, we use the results from real-world profiling to forecast expected load and performance under varying conditions. As a result, our work produces NFV orchestration systems that not only reduce cost and improve adaptivity, but also attain high efficiency and service quality.

Some highlights of the project outcomes include:

1. We have studied the use of OCO (online convex optimization) problems to model the cost and constraints of dynamic orchestration and scaling of NFV systems under significant future uncertainty. 

2. We have developed new online algorithms for OCO problems that can handle both switching costs and ramp constraints. These algorithms are important in capturing the overhead and delay of dynamically adjusting NFV configurations. Further, we design a robustification procedure to produce online algorithms that not only attain good competitive ratios for the worst-case input, but also attain good performance for average-case inputs. 

3. We develop an Elastic resource flexing system for Network functions VIrtualization (ENVI) to make scaling decisions based on an evolving neural network by periodically collecting data on network function and infrastructure resources

4. We have considered the case study of using NFV for the cellular network core, and developed a solution that leverages NFV in this context to combat caller ID spoofing. 

5. We have studied the placement problem in NFV networks. Specifically, we designed a system to enable operators to develop an effective placement strategy for microservice-based Service Function Chains without prior knowledge of service functionality.

6. We have developed new online algorithms for OCO problems with limited look-ahead information. Our algorithm can attain a competitive ratio that not only decreases with the look-ahead window size, but also remains bounded even when the switching cost coefficients are large. 

7. We have studied how to predict failures in queueing systems that model network functions under heavy loads with training data that contains only aggregate statistics of the system under light loads, and no observed losses.

The work from this project has been disseminated through multiple conference and journal publications, and incorporated into graduate-level courses.
